name: Base64 Encoding
description:
Base64 encoding lets you represent arbitrary binary data as ASCII-safe text. Your task is to provide both the encoder and decoder to convert to and from Base64.

Create two functions that can convert from _binary data_ to a _Base64 encoded string_, and vice versa:

```javascript
function toBase64(data: Uint8Array): string
function fromBase64(encoded: string): Uint8Array
```
```python
def to_base_64(data: bytes) -> str: ...
def from_base_64(encoded: str) -> bytes: ...
```
```rust
pub fn to_base64(data: &[u8]) -> String
pub fn from_base64(encoded: &str) -> Vec<u8>
```
```swift
func toBase64(_ data: [UInt8]) -> String
func fromBase64(_ encoded: String) -> [UInt8]
```
```csharp
class Base64Utils {
    string ToBase64(byte[] data)
    byte[] FromBase64(string encoded)
}
```
```c
char *to_base64(size_t byte_count, const uint8_t bytes[byte_count]);
uint8_t *from_base64(const char *base64, size_t *byte_count);
```


While many Base64 implementations use `=` padding characters, your functions should **not** use padding.

_Can you come up with your own encoder and decoder rather than use your language's base64 implementation?_

### Example (input -> output):
```
b'this is a bytestring!' -> "dGhpcyBpcyBhIGJ5dGVzdHJpbmch"
b'\x00' -> "AA"
```

### Tests

- All test inputs will be valid
- There are 100 random encode and 100 random decode tests with input lengths between 25 and 100.

Read more about [Base64 encoding and decoding on Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64).
